Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps Teams: Pathways to Market for ICARUS Algae Cultivation and Harvesting Technology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The days of global dependence on fossil fuels are numbered, as supply cannot sustainably keep up with demand. Next generation fuels must be developed to protect our quality of life, environment, and wallets. Although microalgal biofuels are a promising alternative to fossil fuels, many bottlenecks in large scale cultivation and processing are holding back the industry. These technical challenges include reducing culture collapse due to the invasion of grazers, providing economically viable nutrients, taking advantage of marginal land, and increasing culture density to reduce processing costs. To address these issues, this I-Corps team has developed a cultivation method called the "Isolated Cultivation of Algal Resource Utilizing Selectivity (ICARUS)." ICARUS is a membrane-based method for cultivating microalgae using wastewater, a method that overcomes many of the challenges of large-scale production.

The proposed technology has the potential to impact the public sector (wastewater treatment plants), the private sector (large-scale algal production facilities, biomass processing facilities, biofuel facilities), and academia (R&D of new algal strains). The hybrid technology will encourage an integration of the synergistic goals of the USEPA (wastewater treatment) and the USDOE (development of algae biofuel), meanwhile creating new opportunities for a cutting edge workforce trained in multiple sectors essential to the national economy. Successful commercialization of the proposed technology could make wastewater treatment net energy positive, while making algal biofuels cost-competitive with fossil fuels. ICARUS also provides a platform for a unique public-private business model for algae biofuel production, where typically risk-averse treatment plants may benefit from efficient technology providing additional treatment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The days of global dependence on fossil fuels are numbered, as supply cannot sustainably keep up with demand. Next generation fuels must be developed to protect our quality of life, environment, and wallets. Although microalgal biofuels are a promising alternative to fossil fuels, many bottlenecks in large scale cultivation and processing are holding back the industry. These technical challenges include reducing culture collapse due to the invasion of grazers, providing economically viable nutrients, taking advantage of marginal land, and increasing culture density to reduce processing costs. To address these issues, this I-Corps team has developed a cultivation method called the "Isolated Cultivation of Algal Resource Utilizing Selectivity (ICARUS)." ICARUS is a membrane-based method for cultivating microalgae using wastewater, a method that overcomes many of the challenges of large-scale production.
Intellectual Merit: Through the project, a TRL4 reactor prototype (TRL=technology readiness level), which required engineering research in membrane science, reactor design, microalgal biology, and nutrient uptake kinetics, was developed. Knowledge gained in these particular topic areas are of significant scientific merit not only to engineering fields (wastewater treatment, membrane applications, materials science) but to other fields as well (phycology, marine science, environmental science). The interdisciplinary nature of the ICARUS technology ensured that the research not only drew from multiple scientific fields, but also contribute to their advancement as well. Efficient biomass production and harvesting are two major challenges to current full scale algae biofuel production. ICARUS addressed both: the passive system reduces energy demand and need for external inputs, while the high cell densities promote easier harvesting.

Broader Impacts: The technology has the potential to impact the public sector (wastewater treatment plants), the private sector (large-scale algal production facilities, biomass processing facilities, biofuel facilities), and academia (R&D of new algal strains). The hybrid ICARUS technology encourages an integration of the synergistic goals of the USEPA (wastewater treatment) and the USDOE (development of algae biofuel), meanwhile creating new opportunities for a cutting edge workforce trained in multiple sectors essential to the national economy. Successful commercialization of the technology could make wastewater treatment net energy positive, while making algal biofuels cost-competitive with fossil fuels. ICARUS also provides a platform for a unique public-private business model for algae biofuel production, where typically risk-averse treatment plants may benefit from efficient technology providing additional treatment. Lessons learned from the project was presented at industry related conferences and workshops.

This project led to the filing of one PCT non-provisional patent and two provisional patents. The team learned lean startup methodology, formulated value propositions, prepared a business canvas, and conducted extensive customer discovery to test hypotheses on the value propositions.  Through interviews (>100), the following value propositions for ICARUS were validated:

Wastewater treatment:

- providing additional nutrient removal (final polishing) without additional footprint or significant infrastructure.

- passive operation with low O/M

- no problematic bioproduct (e.g., sludge) generated.

Algae cultivation:

- cultivating different tailored algal crops within the same basin

- maintaining monoculture in outdoor environment

- cultivating algae and producing biomass with low recurring material input (water, nutrients).

Eventual commercialization of the ICARUS technology may potentially yield new markets for harvested algal biomass, lead to a start-up company, and create new employment opportunities.

 


Last Modified: 11/15/2017
Modified by: Daniel H Yeh

Image
  • ICARUS - a novel algae cultivation platform. ICARUS stands for Isolated Cultivation of Algal Resources Utilizing Selectivity
    Ivy Drexler, Melanie Pickett, Daniel Yeh
    Daniel H Yeh
    ICARUS concept

Through interviews (>100), the following value propositions for ICARUS were validated: Wastewater treatment: - providing additional nutrient removal (final polishing) without additional footprint or significant infrastructure. - passive operation with low O/M - no problematic bioproduct (e.g., sludge) generated.
